chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Regardless of whether care is delivered through public programs, private plans, or a mix, most people can agree that no one should be unable to get essential treatment or face devastating medical debt. A practical role for government is to set a universal minimum package of coverage, enforce basic consumer protections and transparency, and provide income-based support so access doesn’t depend on wealth or health status. Within those guardrails, states, employers, providers, and insurers can compete and innovate on service, efficiency, and supplemental options while being held accountable for outcomes and costs.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Most people agree that everyone should be able to get essential care without facing financial ruin, while keeping the system efficient and sustainable. A pragmatic government role is to guarantee a baseline of universal coverage, protect vulnerable patients, and set clear standards for quality, transparency, and fair pricing. Within those guardrails, policies can encourage competition and innovation among public and private providers to improve outcomes and control costs while preserving meaningful choice.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Most people can agree that no one should go without essential care or face financial ruin because they get sick, and that the system must be affordable and accountable to taxpayers. A balanced role for government is to guarantee a basic level of coverage, protect people with preexisting conditions, and require transparent pricing and quality standards. Within those guardrails, private and public options can compete and innovate to improve service, expand provider choice, and control costs.
